dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, trade discussions, right? US, China, all that… and there’s this term, the Real Effective Exchange Rate, REER.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, trade discussions, right? U S, China, all that... and there's this term, the Real Effective Exchange Rate, R E E R.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and uh, the article we're looking at, it kicks off by saying it's, like, totally irrelevant to economic policy? And GVCs, global value chains, are just a myth?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and uh, the article we're looking at, it kicks off by saying it's, like, totally irrelevant to economic policy? And G V Cs, global value chains, are just a myth?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given the REERs importance for economic policy in the current trade discussions between the United States and China, for example central banks and international financial institutions devote considerable resources to calculating and analyzing it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [chuckles] Yeah, well, that's kind of the setup, isn't it? It’s, um, taking a really ironic stance, suggesting central banks have cut resources because they think it's useless.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, well, that's kind of the setup, isn't it? It's, um, taking a really ironic stance, suggesting central banks have cut resources because they think it's useless.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given the REERs importance for economic policy in the current trade discussions between the United States and China, for example central banks and international financial institutions devote considerable resources to calculating and analyzing it.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like, "state-of-the-art methods" mean GVCs don't exist. It's, uh, pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like, state-of-the-art methods mean G V Cs don't exist. It's, uh, pretty wild.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But their methods have become outdated as global value chains (GVCs) become increasingly widespread.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Because the standard way most central banks calculate REER, they basically assume countries *only* import final goods.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Because the standard way most central banks calculate R E E R, they basically assume countries only import final goods.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Standard calculations of the REER by most central banks and statistical agencies assume that countries export only final goods.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, no complex supply chains? Just, uh, raw materials go in, finished product comes out?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, no complex supply chains? Just, uh, raw materials go in, finished product comes out?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. They see GVCs as, quote, "an impossibility." And that ignoring this reality leads to "perfectly reliable policy inferences."
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. They see G V Cs as, quote, an impossibility. And that ignoring this reality leads to perfectly reliable policy inferences.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Ignoring this reality can lead to substantial mismeasurement of the REER, resulting in questionable policy inferences.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which is, [interrupts] of course, completely sarcastic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which is, of course, completely sarcastic.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Completely. And they use this great example: smartphones. Japan imports components, ships them to China for assembly, then China exports.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Completely. And they use this great example: smartphones. Japan imports components, ships them to China for assembly, then China exports.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Suppose Japan manufactures the components and ships them to China, where the phones are assembled and exported globally as finished products.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And traditional REER models would say a weaker Japanese yen would hurt Japan's competitiveness but help China's.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And traditional R E E R models would say a weaker Japanese yen would hurt Japan's competitiveness but help China's.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A depreciation of the Japanese yen, therefore, would help Japans competitiveness and hurt that of China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: But, um, in reality, a weaker yen makes Japanese components more expensive, which could then, like, raise prices for Chinese phones and *decrease* China's competitiveness.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But, um, in reality, a weaker yen makes Japanese components more expensive, which could then, like, raise prices for Chinese phones and decrease China's competitiveness.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In this case, however, a weaker yen would lower the price of Japanese components, which may lead to lower prices and increased demand for Chinese phones leading to an improvement in Chinas competitiveness.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, so it flips the whole thing on its head! I mean, our "rejected framework," as they call it...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, so it flips the whole thing on its head! I mean, our rejected framework, as they call it...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Our proposed framework addresses these problems.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [overlaps] Their *actual* analysis, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Their actual analysis, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! That framework, when it *does* account for GVCs, shows a completely different picture for, say, China's exchange rate against the US dollar.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! That framework, when it does account for G V Cs, shows a completely different picture for, say, China's exchange rate against the U S dollar.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Taking GVCs into account alters our understanding of Chinas bilateral real exchange rate against the US dollar.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A pronounced depreciation trend, versus the standard calculation showing appreciation. Huge difference.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A pronounced depreciation trend, versus the standard calculation showing appreciation. Huge difference.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Once these factors are taken into account, our analysis shows that Chinas real exchange rate against the US dollar displays a pronounced and consistent appreciation trend. By contrast, the standard calculation shows a real depreciation of the renminbi in the period leading up to Chinas abandonment of its exchange-rate peg in 2005...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And even with Greece and Germany, it suggests Greece's competitiveness before the eurozone crisis was actually better than traditionally measured.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And even with Germany, it suggests Greece's competitiveness before the eurozone crisis was actually better than traditionally measured.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Similarly, for the eurozone, our GVC exchange-rate-based measure implies that Greeces loss of competitiveness (or REER appreciation) relative to Germany was worse than the standard measure suggests, and that Greeces competitiveness in the period leading up to the eurozone crisis was thus worse.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, like, all these policy decisions potentially made on, uh, what now seems like flawed data.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, like, all these policy decisions potentially made on, uh, what now seems like flawed data.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Calculating it more accurately could reduce the risk of misguided economic policies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It just makes you wonder, you know? They even say calculating it accurately "could increase the risk of misguided economic policies." It’s, um, quite the statement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It just makes you wonder, you know? They even say calculating it accurately could increase the risk of misguided economic policies. It's, um, quite the statement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Calculating it more accurately could reduce the risk of misguided economic policies.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it really highlights how crucial it is to, like, get these economic models right, especially when global trade is so interconnected.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it really highlights how crucial it is to, like, get these economic models right, especially when global trade is so interconnected.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. It's not just theory; it's real-world policy impact.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. It's not just theory; it's real-world policy impact.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Far from being a theoretical concept confined to economics textbooks, the REER has significant real-world relevance.
